pageContext.description: Flanges in 3 facets tapering to below thin butt, around which a crack suggests casting in a double mould imperfectly [armealed?]. No stop-ridge. Below the centre on one face are 6 slightly raised dots - on both faces are traces of 3 curved ridges concentric with widely splayed cutting edge, which has evidently been reground in antiquity.
pageContext.patina: Appears to have been dark and cleaned off: bright metal visible on edges.
pageContext.surface: Smooth; a few minute cracks; well preserved.
pageContext.other: Width: edge 56mm; centre 21mm; below butt 19mm,Thickness: butt tip 2mm; centre 11mm; height of flanges 17mm,Weight: just over 6 1/4 oz. = 177.1845mm
pageContext.associations: A number of "pieces of brass" were collected from one spot by the workman from whom this axe was obtained, also some pottery: the rest went into the dustbin. Probably part of a bronze hoard.
pageContext.collection: Radcliffe, Lancs.,Museum of the Radcliffe District Lit. and Sc. Soc., 1950.
pageContext.site: England,Lancashire,Radcliffe,Confluence of Rivers Irwell and Ronch,Found in Alluvial soil by workmen of gravel firm.
pageContext.toSearch: 19 Wood Grove, Whitefield, Manchester M45 7st, UK
pageContext.remarks: Found in a prolific area of 100 acres that has produced objects of Mesolithic, Bronze Age, Roman Period during recent exploration.,Information from Mr. Allan Spencer, Hon. Curator, Radcliffe Local History Museum,28.xi.50
